docs.snippet: The F.D.A. makes a pathetic effort to curb antibiotics in agriculture....
docs.abstract: The F.D.A. makes a pathetic effort to curb antibiotics in agriculture.

docs.snippet: After the disappointment that greeted the F.D.A.'s decision not to regulate antibiotics in animal agriculture, the agency delivered a token gesture by announcing a ban on extra-label uses of the cephalosporin, an antibiotic that's been on its way ...
docs.abstract: After the disappointment that greeted the F.D.A.'s decision not to regulate antibiotics in animal agriculture, the agency delivered a token gesture by announcing a ban on extra-label uses of the cephalosporin, an antibiotic that's been on its way out for years.
docs.lead_paragraph: My column last week described how the Food and Drug Administration is declining to regulate the use of antibiotics in animal agriculture. After withdrawing its own 34-year-old request/promise to restrict the routine use of penicillin and tetracyclines in farm animal feed, the F.D.A. made it crystal clear that, despite the increasingly common threat of antibiotic-resistant bacteria in supermarket meat, it would leave the regulating up to industry itself.

docs.lead_paragraph: Spam "bots" tend to be a source of annoyance, flooding the Web with automated nonsensical messages in the hopes of tricking people into clicking on links.

docs.abstract: New books that examine the rise of the American oligarchy, the decline of moderate Republicans and the Tea Party's core beliefs about government
docs.lead_paragraph: In this Sunday's Book Review, three new books are reviewed that respectively examine the rise of the American oligarchy, the decline of moderate Republicans and the Tea Party's core beliefs about government. The polemic among them is Thomas Frank's "Pity the Billionaire," about which Michael Kinsley writes:
